glossary.definition: A means by which people use the Internet to communicate and share information among their immediate friends and to meet and connect with others through common interests, experiences, and friends.
A tool that collects information from e-mails, text messages, blog posts, and Twitter tweets and maps them, making the information instantly publicly available.
One of the first mass-produced microcomputers launched in 1977 and sold in Radio Shack stores.
A microcomputer designed in 1975 and sold in kit form (assembly required). Responsible for launching the microcomputer revolution.
An innovative line of computers introduced by Apple in 1977 that featured unparalleled ease of use (for it time).
First full-featured personal computer produced by Commodore International in 1997.
First personal computer developed by IBM and introduced in 1981.
The design of a computer network; includes both physical and logical design.
A network in which the nodes are located within a small geographic area.
A network in which each node connected to the network can communicate directly with every other node on the network.
The radio waves or the physical system (cable) that transports data on a network.
Cables made of copper wires that are twisted around each other and are surrounded by a plastic jacket (such as traditional home phone wire).
A single copper wire surrounded by layers of plastic insulation, metal sheathing, and a plastic jacket; used mainly in cable television and cable Internet service.
A cable that transmits data at close to the speed of light along glass or plastic fibers.
A device that enables the computer (or peripheral) to communicate with the network using a common data communication language, or protocol.
A small segment of data that’s bundled for sending over transmission media. Each packet contains the address of the computer or peripheral device to which it’s being sent.
A device on a network such as a router, hub, or switch that moves data signals around the network.
A device that routes packets of data between two or more networks.
A device for transmitting data on a network. A switch makes decisions, based on the media access control address of the data, as to where the data is to be sent.

Software that handles requests for information, Internet access, and the use of peripherals for the rest of the network node, providing the services necessary for the computers on the network to communicate.

A company that specializes in providing Internet access. ISPs may be specialized providers, like Juno, or companies that provide other services in addition to Internet access (such as phone and cable television).
A type of connection that uses telephone lines to connect to the Internet and that allows both phone and data transmissions to share the same line.
A specialized computing device designed to store and manage network data.
A device (such as a printer or an external hard drive) that can be attached directly to a network instead of needing to attach to a computer on the network.
Generally accepted principles of right and wrong (usually defined by society) that guide behavior.
Principles of right and wrong that guide a specific individual's behavior.
a branch of psychology that uses theory, research and intervention techniques to decipher and foster the positive, adaptive, creative and emotionally fulfilling aspects of human behavior.
A person who reveals information about illegal activities conducted by a business to authorities or the public.
any person or entity that has an interest in a business (such as employees, customers, suppliers, etc.)
A human being whose physiology is augmented or aided in some way by mechanical or computerized processes.
time required for a disk sector (to which information will be read or written) to position itself below the read-write heads of a hard disk.

Software that is feature complete but still has bugs that has been released to end users for testing. Usually the first software version tested by users outside of the company developing the software.
The discrepancy between those who have access to the opportunities and knowledge that computers and the Internet offer and those who do not.
Tools and web-based services that emphasize online collaboration and sharing among users.
Any method of confirming the identity of an authorized system user, such as requiring a logon name and password to gain access to a website.
Software that enables an operating system to communicate with a specific hardware device.
A combination of an email address and a password that you allows you to sign in to Microsoft services such as Windows 8, Hotmail, Messenger, and SkyDrive.
The combination of leisure time and the tools needed to be creative.
Asking for small donations from a large number of people, often using the Internet; a style of generating capital to start a business through social media.
Technology that lets any piece of print in the real world host a live link to online information and video content.
Joining together as a group to use a specific product more efficiently.
Unwanted or junk e-mail.
The set of computer programs or instructions that tells the computer what to do and that enables it to perform different tasks.
The set of techniques used in processing and retrieving information.
The process by which great amounts of data are analyzed and investigated. The objective is to spot significant patterns or trends within the data that would otherwise not be obvious.
The application of computer systems and techniques to gather potential legal evidence; a law enforcement specialty used to fight high-tech crime.
A combination of our normal sense of the objects around us with an overlay of information displayed.
A type of computing that relates to emotion or that deliberately tries to influence emotion.
An expansion card that enables a computer to produce omnidirectional or three-dimensional sounds.
The time it takes a storage device to locate its stored data.

An application program that helps business owners manage their finances more efficiently by providing tools for tracking accounting transactions such as sales, accounts receivable, inventory purchases, and accounts payable.

A program that downloads on your computer when a user installs a freeware program, game, or utility. Generally, adware enables sponsored advertisements to appear in a section of a browser window or as a pop-up ad.
A type of computing that relates to emotion or that deliberately tries to influence emotion.
A software program that finds and retrieves the latest update of web material (usually podcasts) according to your specifications.
A desktop system unit that houses the computer’s processor, memory, and monitor in a single unit.
Combines the functions of a printer, scanner, copier, and fax into one machine.
Waves that illustrate the loudness of a sound or the brightness of the colors in an image at a given moment in time.
Converts analog signals into digital signals.
Software specifically designed to detect viruses and protect a computer and files from harm.
Bars that float above the screen and that contain applications such as the Tabs bar and the Address bar; a new feature of Internet Explorer 10.
A set of software routines that allows one software system to work with another.

The set of programs on a computer that helps a user carry out tasks such as word processing, sending e-mail, balancing a budget, creating presentations, editing photos, taking an online course, and playing games.
The width-to-height proportion of a monitor.
A second-generation language that is easier for humans to work with than binary
Programs that perform basic editing tasks on audio files such as cutting dead air space from the beginning or end of a song or cutting a portion from the middle.
Interface technology that allows a user to connect guitars and microphones to their computer.
A combination of our normal sense of the objects around us with an overlay of information displayed.
Program that enables a hacker to take complete control of a computer without the legitimate user’s knowledge or permission.
A copy of a computer file that can be used to replace the original if it’s lost or damaged.
The accommodation of current devices being able to use previously issued software standards in addition to the current standards.
The maximum speed at which data can be transmitted between two nodes on a network; usually measured in megabits per second (Mbps). See also data transfer rate.
A large communications tower with antennas, amplifiers, and receivers/transmitters.

program that manages the data between a computer’s operating system and all the input and output devices attached to the computer; also responsible for loading the operating system (OS) from its permanent location on the hard drive to random access memory (RAM).
A digit that corresponds to the on and off states of a computer’s switches. A bit contains a value of either 0 or 1.
The language computers use to process data into information, consisting of only the values 0 and 1.
A hacker who uses his or her knowledge to destroy information or for illegal gain.
A personal log or journal posted on the web; short for web log.

A type of wireless technology that uses radio waves to transmit data over short distances (approximately 3-300 feet depending on power); often used to connect peripherals such as printers and keyboards to computers or headsets to cell phones.
A method of optical storage for digital data, developed for storing high-definition media. It has the largest storage capacity of all optical storage options.
Features in some browsers that place markers of websites’ Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) in an easily retrievable list.
A word used to refine logical searches. For Internet searches, the words AND, NOT, and OR describe the relationships between keywords in the search.
The process for loading the operating system (OS) into random access memory (RAM) when the computer is turned on.
A virus that replicates itself into the master boot record of a flash drive or hard drive.
A large group of software applications (called robots or bots) that run without user intervention on a large number of computers.
A navigation aid that shows users the path they have taken to get to a web page or where the page is located within the website; it usually appears at the top of a page.
A high-speed Internet connection such as cable, satellite, or digital subscriber line (DSL).
E-commerce transactions between businesses.
E-commerce transactions between businesses and consumers.
Eight binary digits (bits).
A broadband service that transmits data over coaxial cables.

Small blocks of memory, located directly on and next to the central processing unit (CPU) chip, that act as holding places for recently or frequently used instructions or data that the CPU accesses the most. When these instructions or data are stored in cache memory, the CPU can more quickly retrieve them than if it had to access the instructions or data from random access memory (RAM).
A UTP cable type that provides more than 1 Gb/s of throughput.
A telephone that operates over a mobile network. Cell phones can also offer Internet access, text messaging, personal information management (PIM) features, and more.

The part of the system unit of a computer that is responsible for data processing; it is the largest and most important chip in the computer. The CPU controls all the functions performed by the computer’s other components and processes all the commands issued to it by software instructions.
Special shortcuts for performing common tasks, such as searching or sharing information, created for Windows 8.
A computer that requests information from a server in a client/server network (such as your computer when you are connected to the Internet).
The pace by which the computer moves from process to process, measured in hertz (Hz) describes how many times something happens per second.
The process of storing data, files, and applications on the web, which allows access to and manipulation of these files and applications from any Internet-connected device.
The smallest increment in which data is stored on hard disks; hard disks are divided into , then wedges, then sectors, then clusters.
A rule, implemented in either software or hardware, which squeezes a given amount of audio and video information into less space.
The combination of leisure time and the tools needed to be creative.
The process of starting a computer from a powered-down or off state.
Joining together as a group to use a specific product more efficiently.
Interface between user and computer in which the user enters commands to communicate with the computer system.
A method of optical storage for digital data; originally developed for storing digital audio.
A data-processing device that gathers, processes, outputs, and stores data and information.
A 3-D modeling program used to create automated designs, technical drawings, and model visualizations.
The application of computer systems and techniques to gather potential legal evidence; a law enforcement specialty used to fight high-tech crime.
Being familiar enough with computers that a user knows how to use them and understands their capabilities and limitations.
A port that enables a computing device to be connected to other devices or systems such as networks, modems, and the Internet.
E-commerce transactions between consumers through online sites such as eBay.com.
A small text file that some websites automatically store on a client computer’s hard drive when a user visits the site.
A simplified licensing scheme that enables copyright holders to grant certain rights to a work while retaining other rights.
A complete processing section from a central processing unit, embedded into one physical chip.

A program that provides traditional classroom tools, such as calendars and grade books, over the Internet, as well as areas for students to exchange ideas and information in chat rooms, discussion forums, and e-mail.
Measurements used to compare performance between processors.
The percentage of time the central processing unit (CPU) is working.
Records your central processing unit (CPU) usage for the past several seconds.
A tool that collects information from e-mails, text messages, blog posts, and Twitter tweets and maps them, making the information instantly publicly available.
Asking for small donations from a large number of people, often using the Internet; a style of generating capital to start a business through social media.
The phenomenon of consumers checking in with the voice of the crowd before making purchases.
The process of installing only those features of a software program that a user wants on the hard drive.
Any criminal action perpetrated primarily through the use of a computer.
An individual who uses computers, networks, and the Internet to perpetrate crime.
Doing anything with a computer that’s unrelated to a job (such as playing video games) while one’s supposed to be working. Also called cyberslacking.
Numbers, words, pictures, or sounds that represent facts, figures, or ideas; the raw input that users have at the start of a job.
When sensitive or confidential information is copied, transmitted, or viewed by an individual who is not authorized to handle the data.
A file that contains stored data.
A connectivity plan or text messaging plan in which data charges are separate from cell phone calling charges and are provided at rates different from those for voice calls.
The maximum speed at which data can be transmitted between two nodes on a network; measured in megabits per second (Mbps) or gigabits per second (Gbps).
An electronic filing system best used for larger and more complicated groups of data that require more than one table and the ability to group, sort, and retrieve data and generate reports.

An attack that occurs when legitimate users are denied access to a computer system because a hacker is repeatedly making requests of that computer system that tie up its resources and deny legitimate users access.
A computer that’s intended for use at a single location. A desktop computer consists of a case that houses the main components of the computer, plus peripheral devices.
Programs for incorporating and arranging graphics and text to produce creative documents.
The use of a single unifying device to handle media, Internet, entertainment, and telephony needs; expressed in the range of devices now on the market.
The discrepancy between those who have access to the opportunities and knowledge that computers and the Internet offer and those who do not.
A system of access control that allows only limited use of material that has been legally purchased.
A specialized chip that processes digital information and transmits signals very quickly.
A type of connection that uses telephone lines to connect to the Internet and that allows both phone and data transmissions to share the same line.
A method of optical storage for digital data that has greater storage capacity than compact discs.
A program for editing digital video.
Video interface technology that newer LCD monitors, as well as other multimedia devices such as televisions, DVD players, and projectors, use to connect to a PC.
A hierarchical structure that include files, folders, and drives used to create a more organized and efficient computer.
A Windows utility that removes unnecessary files from the hard drive.
A utility that regroups related pieces of files on the hard drive, enabling faster retrieval of the data.
An automated attack that’s launched from more than one zombie computer at the same time.
Linux download packages.

A part of a Uniform Resource Locator (URL). Domain names consist of two parts: the site’s host and a suffix that indicates the type of organization (example: popsci.com, where popsci is the domain name and com is the suffix).
Programs for creating or editing two-dimensional line-based drawings.
A special shelf inside a computer that is designed to hold storage devices.
The use of malicious software to attack a computer by downloading harmful programs onto a computer, without the user’s knowledge, while they are surfing a website.
The process of conducting business online for purposes ranging from fund-raising to advertising to selling products.
A very crisp, sharp grayscale representation of text achieved by using millions of microcapsules with white and black particles in a clear fluid.
Textual information stored as digital information so that it can be stored, manipulated, and transmitted by electronic devices.
Internet-based communication in which senders and recipients correspond.
A software program that runs on a computer and is used to send and receive e-mail through an Internet service provider’s server.
A virus transmitted by e-mail that often uses the address book in the victim’s e-mail system to distribute itself.

A specially designed computer chip that resides inside another device, such as a car. These self-contained computer devices have their own programming and typically neither receive input from users nor interact with other systems.
A malicious program that searches for common data files and compresses them into a file using a complex encryption key, thereby rendering the files unusable.
See software license.
A device that can display e-text and that has supporting tools, like note taking, bookmarks, and integrated dictionaries.
How a user sets up his or her computer and other equipment to minimize risk of injury or discomfort.
A Windows utility that checks for lost files and fragments as well as physical errors on a hard drive.
A network that uses the Ethernet protocol as the means (or standard) by which the nodes on the network communicate.
A port that’s slightly larger than a standard phone jack and that transfers data at speeds of up to 10,000 Mbps; used to connect a computer to a DSL or cable modem or to a network.
The result of an action, such as a keystroke, mouse click, or signal to the printer, in the respective device (keyboard, mouse, or printer) to which the operating system responds.
A circuit board with specific functions that augment the computer’s basic functions and provide connections to other devices; examples include the sound card and the video card.
Laptops are often equipped with an ExpressCard slot. The ExpressCard can add a solid-state drive (SSD), new kinds of ports, and other capabilities to a system.

In a file name, the three letters that follow the user-supplied file name after the dot (.); the extension identifies what kind of family of files the file belongs to, or which application should be used to read the file.
A hard drive that is enclosed in a protective case to make it portable; the drive is connected to the computer with a data transfer cable and is often used to back up data.

A feature in Microsoft Internet Explorer that places a marker of a website’s Uniform Resource Locator (URL) in an easily retrievable list in the browser’s toolbar. (Called Bookmarks in some browsers.)
Inexpensive cell phones with modest processors, simple interfaces, and, often, no touch screens.
Internet access that is enabled by transmitting data at the speed of light through glass or plastic fibers.
A collection of related pieces of information stored together for easy reference.
An index of all sector numbers that the hard drive stores in a table to keep track of which sectors hold which files.
A program that takes out redundancies in a file in order to reduce the file size.
The main tool for finding, viewing, and managing the contents of your computer by showing the location and contents of every drive, folder, and file; called Windows Explorer prior to Windows 8.
A Windows utility that automatically creates a duplicate of your libraries, desktop, contacts, and favorites and copies it to another storage device, such as an external hard drive.
The process by which humans or computer software provide organizational structure to a computer’s contents.
The first part of the label applied to a file; generally the name a user assigns to the file when saving it.

The exact location of a file, starting with the drive in which the file is located and including all folders, subfolders (if any), the file name, and the extension (example: C:\Users\username\Documents\Illustrations\EBronte.jpg).
A protocol used to upload and download files from one computer to another over the Internet.
Programs for managing finances, such as Intuit’s Quicken, which include electronic checkbook registers and automatic bill-payment tools.
A software program or hardware device designed to prevent unauthorized access to computers or networks.
An interface port that transfers data at 400 Mbps.
An interface port that transfers data at 800 Mbps.
System software that controls hardware devices.
A drive that plugs into a universal serial bus (USB) port on a computer and that stores data digitally. Also called a USB drive, jump drive, or thumb drive.
A form of portable storage; this removable memory card is often used in digital cameras, smartphones, video cameras, and printers.
A collection of files stored on a computer.
Any copyrighted software that can be used for free.
The process of installing all the files and programs from the distribution media to the computer’s hard drive.
Data attached to a photograph that indicates the latitude and longitude where you were standing when you took the photo.
The most commonly used wired Ethernet standard deployed in devices designed for home networks; provides bandwidth of up to 1 Gbps.
About a billion bytes.
One billion hertz.

A system of 21 satellites (plus 3 working spares), built and operated by the U.S. military, that constantly orbit the earth. The satellites provide information to GPS–capable devices to pinpoint locations on the earth.
Unlike the command- and menu-driven interfaces used in earlier software, GUIs display graphics and use the point-and-click technology of the mouse and cursor, making them much more user-friendly.
A standard of video memory.
A specialized logic chip that’s dedicated to quickly displaying and calculating visual data such as shadows, textures, and luminosity.

A cross between black and white—a hacker who will often illegally break into systems merely to flaunt his or her expertise to the administrator of the system he or she penetrated or to attempt to sell his or her services in repairing security breaches.
Anyone who unlawfully breaks into a computer system (whether an individual computer or a network).
The computer’s nonvolatile, primary storage device for permanent storage of software and documents.
Any part of a computer or computer system you can physically touch.
Impact of the read/write head against the magnetic platter of the hard drive; often results in data loss.
A power-management mode that saves the current state of the current system to the computer’s hard drive.
A standard of digital TV signal that guarantees a specific level of resolution and a specific aspect ratio, which is the rectangular shape of the image.
A compact audio–video interface standard that carries both high-definition video and uncompressed digital audio.
A network located in a home that’s used to connect all of its digital devices.
A device designed to store media, share media across the network, and back up files on computers connected to a home network.
The portion of a domain name that identifies who maintains a given website. For example, berkeley.edu is the domain name for the University of California at Berkeley, which maintains that site.
A type of specially coded text that, when clicked, enables a user to jump from one location, or web page, to another within a website or to another website altogether.
A technology that permits quicker processing of information by enabling a new set of instructions to start executing before the previous set has finished.

The process by which someone uses personal information about someone else (such as the victim’s name, address, and Social Security number) to assume the victim’s identity for the purpose of defrauding another.
A copy of an entire computer system, created for restoration purposes.
Programs for editing photographs and other images.
A printer that has tiny hammer-like keys that strike the paper through an inked ribbon, thus making a mark on the paper. The most common impact printer is the dot-matrix printer.
A type of backup that only backs up files that have changed since the last time files were backed up.
Data that has been organized or presented in a meaningful fashion; the result, or output that users require at the end of a job.
The set of techniques used in processing and retrieving information.
A nonimpact printer that sprays tiny drops of ink onto paper.
A process used by antivirus software; compares old and current qualities of files to detect viral activity.
A hardware device used to enter, or input, data (text, images, and sounds) and instructions (user responses and commands) into a computer. Some input devices are keyboards and mice.
A program that enables users to communicate online in real time with others who are also online.
A hard drive that resides within the computer’s system unit and that usually holds all permanently stored programs and data.
A network of networks that’s the largest network in the world, connecting billions of computers globally.
The means by which all computers connected to the Internet identify each other. It consists of a unique set of four numbers separated by dots, such as 123.45.178.91.

A company that specializes in providing Internet access. ISPs may be specialized providers, like Juno, or companies that provide other services in addition to Internet access (such as phone and cable television).
A signal that tells the operating system that it’s in need of immediate attention.
A special numerical code that prioritizes requests from various devices. These requests then are placed in the interrupt table in the computer’s primary memory.

The essential component of the operating system that’s responsible for managing the processor and all other components of the computer system. Because it stays in random access memory (RAM) the entire time the computer is powered on, the kernel is called memory resident.
A hardware device used to enter typed data and commands into a computer.
A type of spyware program that monitors keystrokes with the intent of stealing passwords, login IDs, or credit card information.
(1) A specific word a user wishes to query (or look for) in an Internet search. (2) A specific word that has a predefined meaning in a particular programming language.
A unit of computer storage equal to approximately 1,000 bytes.
A portable computer with a keyboard, a monitor, and other devices integrated into a single compact case.
A nonimpact printer known for quick and quiet production and high-quality printouts.
The process that occurs after the read/write head of the hard drive locates the correct track and then waits for the correct sector to spin to the read/write head.
Comprises computing devices, software, or peripherals that use techniques, parts, and methods from an earlier time that are no longer popular.

Introduced with Windows 7, a folder that’s used to display files from different locations as if they were all saved in a single folder, regardless of where they are actually stored in the file hierarchy.
A newer, more energy-efficient technology used in monitors. It may result in better color accuracy and thinner panels than traditional LCD monitors.
An open-source operating system based on UNIX. Because of the stable nature of this operating system, it’s often used on web servers.
The technology used in flat-panel computer monitors.
A bookmark that delivers updates as soon as they become available, using Really Simple Syndication (RSS).
A computer virus that runs when a certain set of conditions is met, such as when a program is launched a specific number of times.
A virtual communications gateway or path that enables a computer to organize requests for information (such as web page downloads and e-mail routing) from other networks or computers.
A condition in which a firewall is configured to ignore all incoming packets that request access to a certain port so that no unwanted requests will get through to the computer.
The first commercially available operating system to incorporate a graphical user interface (GUI) with user-friendly point-and-click technology.
The series of steps a central processing unit goes through when it performs a program instruction.
A small program that groups a series of commands to run as a single command.
A virus that’s distributed by hiding it inside a macro.
A large, expensive computer that supports hundreds or thousands of users simultaneously and executes many different programs at the same time.

Software that’s intended to render a system temporarily or permanently useless or to penetrate a computer system completely for purposes of information gathering. Examples include spyware, viruses, worms, and Trojan horses.
A small program that runs whenever a computer boots up.
A unit of computer storage equal to approximately 1 million bytes.
A small circuit board that holds a series of random access memory (RAM) chips.
A user interface in which the user chooses a command from menus displayed on the screen.
A search engine, such as Dogpile, that searches other search engines rather than individual websites.
A wide area network (WAN) that links users in a specific geographic area (such as within a city or county).
A device that allows you to capture sound waves, such as those created by your voice, and to transfer them to digital format on your computer.
Connection to the Internet through the same cellular network that cell phones use to get 3G or 4G Internet access.
A central location that receives cell phone requests for service from a base station.
A port that uses a traditional telephone signal to connect a computer to the Internet.
A common output device that displays text, graphics, and video as soft copies (copies that can be seen only on screen).
A prediction, named after Gordon Moore, the co-founder of Intel; states that the number of transistors on a central processing unit chip will double every two years.

A special circuit board in the system unit that contains the central processing unit, the memory (RAM) chips, and the slots available for expansion cards; all of the other boards (video cards, sound cards, and so on) connect to it to receive power and to communicate.
A hardware device used to enter user responses and commands into a computer.
Anything that involves one or more forms of media plus text.
Programs that include image-, video-, and audio-editing software, animation software, and other specialty software required to produce computer games, animations, and movies.
Literally meaning “multipart” virus; a type of computer virus that attempts to infect computers using more than one method.
The ability of an operating system to perform more than one process at a time.
An operating system that enables more than one user to access the computer system at one time by efficiently juggling all the requests from multiple users.
A computing device that runs a full-featured operating system but that weighs two pounds or less.
A group of two or more computers (or nodes) that are configured to share information and resources such as printers, files, and databases.
A process that firewalls use to assign internal Internet protocol addresses on a network.

Involves tasks such as (1) installing new computers and devices, (2) monitoring the network to ensure it’s performing efficiently, (3) updating and installing new software on the network, and (4) configuring, or setting up, proper security for a network.
The design of a computer network; includes both physical and logical design.
A specialized computing device designed to store and manage network data.
An expansion card that enables a computer to connect other computers or to a cable modem to facilitate a high-speed Internet connection.
A device on a network such as a router or switch that moves data signals around the network.
A device (such as a printer or an external hard drive) that can be attached directly to a network instead of needing to attach to a computer on the network.
A device connected to a network such as a computer, a peripheral (such as a printer), or a communications device (such as a modem).
A printer that sprays ink or uses laser beams to make marks on the paper. The most common nonimpact printers are inkjet and laser printers.
Permanent storage, as in read-only memory (ROM).
Program code made publicly available for free; it can be copied, distributed, or changed without the stringent copyright protections of proprietary software products.
The system software that controls the way in which a computer system functions, including the management of hardware, peripherals, and software.
A hardware device that uses lasers or light to read from, and even write to, CDs, DVDs, or Blu-ray discs.
Portable storage devices, such as CDs, DVDs, and Blu-ray discs, that use a laser to read and write data.
A mouse that uses an internal sensor or laser to control the mouse’s movement. The sensor sends signals to the computer, telling it where to move the pointer on the screen.

Displays that use organic compounds to produce light when exposed to an electric current. Unlike LCDs, OLEDs do not require a backlight to function and therefore draw less power and have a much thinner display, sometimes as thin as 3 mm.
A device that sends processed data and information out of a computer in the form of text, pictures (graphics), sounds (audio), or video.
Running the central processing unit at a speed faster than the manufacturer recommends.
A computer hardware device or software program designed to detect and record digital information being transmitted over a network.

The process of swapping data or instructions that have been placed in the swap file for later use back into active random access memory (RAM). The contents of the hard drive’s swap file then become less active data or instructions.
The information after the slash that indicates a particular file or path (or subdirectory) within the website.
The backslash mark (\) used by Microsoft Windows and DOS in file names. Mac files use a colon (:), and UNIX and Linux use the forward slash (/) as the path separator.
A network in which each node connected to the network can communicate directly with every other node on the network.
The process of users transferring files between computers.
A device such as a monitor, printer, or keyboard that connects to the system unit through a data port.
A network used for communication among devices close to one person, such as smartphones, laptops, and tablets, using wireless technologies such as Bluetooth.
A firewall specifically designed for home networks.
Programs such as Microsoft Outlook or Lotus Organizer that strive to replace the various management tools found on a traditional desk such as a calendar, address book, notepad, and to-do lists.
A unit of data measurement equal to 1 million gigabytes or 1 thousand terabytes.
Planting malicious code on a computer that alters the browser’s ability to find web addresses and that directs users to bogus websites.

The process of sending e-mail messages to lure Internet users into revealing personal information such as credit card or Social Security numbers or other sensitive information that could lead to identity theft.
The amount of random access memory (RAM) that’s installed in a computer.
The process of connecting to a wireless network without the permission of the owner of the network.
The process through which you choose which applications are visible on the Windows Start screen.

A single point that creates the images on a computer monitor. Pixels are illuminated by an electron beam that passes rapidly back and forth across the back of the screen so that the pixels appear to glow continuously.
The combination of a computer’s operating system and processor. The two most common platform types are the PC and the Apple.
A thin, round, metallic storage plate stacked onto the hard drive spindle.
A large printer that uses a computer-controlled pen to produce oversize pictures that require precise continuous lines to be drawn, such as maps and architectural plans.
The technology that enables the operating system, once it is booted up, to recognize automatically any new peripherals and to configure them to work with the system.
A small software program that “plugs in” to a web browser to enable a specific function—for example, to view and hear certain multimedia files on the web.
A clip of audio or video content that’s broadcast over the Internet using compressed audio or video files in formats such as MP3.

A virus that changes its virus signature (the binary pattern that makes the virus identifiable) every time it infects a new file. This makes it more difficult for antivirus programs to detect the virus.
An interface through which external devices are connected to the computer.

The first job the basic input/output system (BIOS) performs, ensuring that essential peripheral devices are attached and operational. This process consists of a test on the video card and video memory, a BIOS identification process (during which the BIOS version, manufacturer, and data are displayed on the monitor), and a memory test to ensure memory chips are working properly.
A power supply regulates the wall voltage to the voltages required by computer chips; it’s housed inside the system unit.
When the operating system processes the task assigned a higher priority before processing a task that has been assigned a lower priority.
An application program for creating dynamic slide shows, such as Microsoft PowerPoint or Apple Keynote.
The act of creating an invented scenario (the pretext) to convince someone to divulge information.
A common output device that creates tangible or hard copies of text and graphics.
Manipulating or organizing data into information.

Programs that enable a user to perform various tasks generally required in home, school, and business. Examples include word processing, spreadsheet, presentation, personal information management, and database programs.
A series of instructions to be followed by a computer to accomplish a task.
Files that are used in the running of software programs and that do not store data.
A device that can project images from your computer onto a wall or viewing screen.
Custom software application that’s owned and controlled by the company that created it.
The placement (by antivirus software) of a computer virus in a secure area on the hard drive so that it won’t spread infection to other files.
Technology that lets any piece of print in the real world host a live link to online information and video content.
A keyboard that gets its name from the first six letters on the top-left row of alphabetic keys on the keyboard.
The strategy of running two hard drives in one system, cutting in half the time it takes to write a file.
The strategy of mirroring all the data written on one hard drive to a second hard drive, providing an instant backup of all data.
The computer’s temporary storage space or short-term memory. It’s located in a set of chips on the system unit’s motherboard, and its capacity is measured in megabytes or gigabytes.
A set of memory chips, located on the motherboard, which stores data and instructions that cannot be changed or erased; it holds all the instructions the computer needs to start up.
The mechanism that retrieves (reads) and records (writes) the magnetic data to and from a data disk.

A program with a specific purpose that must guarantee certain response times for particular computing tasks or else the machine’s application is useless. Real-time operating systems are found in many types of robotic equipment.
An XML–based format that allows frequent updates of content on the World Wide Web.
A folder on a Windows desktop in which deleted files from the hard drive are held until permanently purged from the system.
A set of strategies for using more than one drive in a system.
A new utility program in Windows 8 that attempts to diagnose and fix errors in your Windows system files that are causing your computer to behave improperly.
A portion of the hard drive containing all the different configurations (settings) used by the Windows operating system as well as by other applications.
The clearness or sharpness of an image, which is controlled by the number of pixels displayed on the screen.
The top level of the filing structure in a computer system. In Windows computers, the root directory of the hard drive is represented as C:\.

Programs that allow hackers to gain access to your computer and take almost complete control of it without your knowledge. These programs are designed to subvert normal login procedures to a computer and to hide their operations from normal detection methods.
The number of times per second a signal is measured and converted to a digital value. Sampling rates are measured in kilobits per second.

A way to connect to the Internet using a small satellite dish, which is placed outside the home and is connected to a computer with coaxial cable. The satellite company then sends the data to a satellite orbiting the Earth. The satellite, in turn, sends the data back to the satellite dish and to the computer.
A type of input device that inputs images into computers.
A type of malware that’s downloaded onto your computer and that tries to convince you that your computer is infected with a virus or other type of malware.
A list of commands (mini-programs or macros) that can be executed on a computer without user interaction.
A set of programs that searches the web for specific words (or keywords) you wish to query (or look for) and that then returns a list of the websites on which those keywords are found.
A section of a hard drive platter, wedge-shaped from the center of the platter to the edge.
The time it takes for the hard drive’s read/write heads to move over the surface of the disk to the correct track.
An evolving extension of the World Wide Web in which information is defined in such a way as to make it more easily readable by computers.
A computer that provides resources to other computers on a network.
A network name that wireless routers use to identify themselves.
Technology that enables short text messages (up to 160 characters) to be sent over mobile networks.
Software, often used for training purposes, which allows the user to experience or control an event as if it’s reality.

A low-power mode for electronic devices such as computers that saves electric power consumption and saves the last-used settings. When the device is “woken up,” work is resumed more quickly than when cold booting the computer.
A cell phone built on a full-featured mobile operating system that offers computing capability and connectivity beyond those offered by basic phones.
A keyword or term that Internet users assign to a web resource such as a web page, digital image, or video.
A subset of e-commerce that uses social networks to assist in marketing and purchasing products.
Any technique that uses social skills to generate human interaction for the purpose of enticing individuals to reveal sensitive information.
A means by which people use the Internet to communicate and share information among their immediate friends and to meet and connect with others through common interests, experiences, and friends.
The set of computer programs or instructions that tells the computer what to do and that enables it to perform different tasks.
Software that’s delivered on demand over the Internet.
An agreement between the user and the software developer that must be accepted before installing the software on a computer.
Violating a software license agreement by copying an application onto more computers than the license agreement permits.
A collection of software programs that have been bundled together as a package.
A storage device that uses the same kind of memory that flash drives use but that can reach data in only a tenth of the time a flash drive requires.
An expansion card that attaches to the motherboard inside the system unit and that enables the computer to produce sounds by providing a connection for the speakers and microphone.
Unwanted or junk e-mail.
An option you can select in your e-mail account that places known or suspected spam messages into a folder other than your inbox.
Output devices for sound.
A targeted phishing attack that sends e-mails to people known to be customers of a company. Such attacks have a much greater chance of successfully getting individuals to reveal sensitive data.
A program that helps coordinate all print jobs being sent to the printer at the same time.
An application program such as Microsoft Excel or Lotus 1-2-3 that enables a user to do calculations and numerical analyses easily.
An unwanted piggyback program that downloads with the software you want to install from the Internet and then runs in the background of your system.
The first interaction you have with the Windows operating system and the pace where you begin your computing activities.
A virus that temporarily erases its code from the files where it resides and hides in the active memory of the computer.
Technology that enables audio files to be fed to a browser continuously. This lets users avoid having to download an entire file before listening.
Technology that enables video files to be fed to a browser continuously. This lets users avoid having to download the entire file before viewing.
A pen-shaped device used to tap or write on touch-sensitive screens.
A structured outline of websites organized by topics and subtopics.

A specially designed computer that can perform complex calculations extremely rapidly; used in situations in which complex models requiring intensive mathematical calculations are needed (such as weather forecasting or atomic energy research).
A memory-management technique used by Windows 7. Monitors the applications you use the most and preloads them into your system memory so that they’ll be ready to go.
A device that protects computers and other electronic devices from power surges.
A type of audio processing that makes the listener experience sound as if it were coming from all directions.
A system of speakers set up in such a way that it surrounds an entire area (and the people in it) with sound.

A temporary storage area on the hard drive where the operating system “swaps out” or moves the data or instructions from random access memory (RAM) that haven’t recently been used. This process takes place when more RAM space is needed.
The process of updating data on portable devices (such as a cell phone or iPod) and a computer so that they contain the same data.

The process of looking at a computer’s subsystems, what they do, and how they perform to determine whether the computer system has the right hardware components to do what the user ultimately wants it to do.
The main files of an operating system.
The set of minimum storage, memory capacity, and processing standards recommended by the software manufacturer to ensure proper operation of a software application.
A utility in Windows that restores system settings to a specific previous date when everything was working properly.
In Windows, a snapshot of your entire system’s settings used for restoring your system to a prior point in time.
The set of programs that enables a computer’s hardware devices and application software to work together; it includes the operating system and utility programs.

The metal or plastic case that holds all the physical parts of the computer together, including the computer’s processor (its brains), its memory, and the many circuit boards that help the computer function.

A mobile computer, such as the Apple iPad or Samsung Galaxy Tab, integrated into a flat multitouch-sensitive screen. It uses an onscreen virtual keyboard, but separate keyboards can be connected via Bluetooth or wires.
A laptop computer designed specifically to work with handwriting-recognition technology.
A Windows utility that shows programs currently running and permits you to exit nonresponsive programs when you click End Task.
In later versions of Windows operating systems, a feature that displays open and favorite applications for easy access.

An application program, such as Intuit’s TurboTax or H&R Block’s At Home, for preparing state and federal taxes. Each program offers a complete set of tax forms and instructions as well as expert advice on how to complete each form.
The use of equipment to provide voice communications over a distance.
A form included in many productivity applications that provides the basic structure for a particular kind of document, spreadsheet, or presentation.
1,099,511,627,776 bytes or 2<sup>40</sup> bytes.

Approach which makes sure that as long as you have a 3G signal, your computer can access the Internet even when it tells you there are no available wireless networks. Several smartphones offer this capability.

A printer that works either by melting wax-based ink onto ordinary paper (in a process called thermal wax transfer printing or by burning dots onto specially coated paper (in a process called direct thermal printing.
A condition of excessive paging in which the operating system becomes sluggish.
The actual speed of data transfer that’s achieved. It’s usually less than the data transfer rate and is measured in megabits per second (Mbps).
A virus that’s triggered by the passage of time or on a certain date.
The suffix, often of three letters (such as .com or .edu), in the domain name that indicates the kind of organization the host is.
A small, touch-sensitive screen at the base of a laptop keyboard that’s used to direct the cursor.
A type of monitor (or display in a smartphone or tablet computer) that accepts input from a user touching the screen.
A concentric circle that serves as a storage area on a hard drive platter.
A small, joystick-like nub that enables you to move the cursor with the tip of your finger.
A computer program that appears to be something useful or desirable (such as a game or a screen saver), but at the same time does something malicious in the background without the user’s knowledge.

A full-featured but lightweight laptop computer that features a low-power processor and a solid-state drive; it tries to reduce its size and weight to extend battery life without sacrificing performance.
A website’s unique address; an example is microsoft.com.
A device designed to power a computer from large batteries for a brief period during a loss of electrical power.
A port that can connect a wide variety of peripheral devices to the computer, including keyboards, printers, mice, smartphones, external hard drives, flash drives, and digital cameras.

An operating system originally conceived in 1969 by Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie of AT&T’s Bell Labs. In 1974, the UNIX code was rewritten in the standard programming language C. Today there are various commercial versions of UNIX.
The most popular transmission media option for Ethernet networks. UTP cable is composed of four pairs of wires that are twisted around each other to reduce electrical interference.
Part of the operating system that enables individuals to interact with the computer.
A small program that performs many of the general housekeeping tasks for the computer, such as system maintenance and file compression.

Software that’s developed for and customized to a specific industry’s needs (such as a wood inventory system for a sawmill) as opposed to software that’s useful across a range of industries (such as word processing software).
An expansion card that’s installed inside a system unit to translate binary data (the 1s and 0s the computer uses) into the images viewed on the monitor.
A port to which a cathode ray tube monitor connects.
A personal online journal that uses video as the primary content in addition to text, images, and audio.
Random access memory that’s included as part of a video card.
The space on the hard drive where the operating system stores data if there isn’t enough random access memory to hold all of the programs you’re currently trying to run.
A computer program that attaches itself to another computer program (known as the host program) and attempts to spread itself to other computers when files are exchanged.
A portion of the virus code that’s unique to a particular computer virus and that makes it identifiable by antivirus software.
A technology that facilitates making telephone calls across the Internet instead of using conventional telephone lines.
Temporary storage, such as in random access memory. When the power is off, the data in volatile storage is cleared out.
The process of restarting the system while it’s powered on.
Tools and web-based services that emphasize online collaboration and sharing among users.
A program that’s hosted on a website and that doesn’t require installation on the computer.
A type of e-mail system that’s managed by a web browser and that allows access to e-mail from the web.
Software installed on a computer system that allows individuals to locate, view, and navigate the web.
Programs you can use to design interactive web pages without knowing any HyperText Markup Language (HTML) code.
A small camera that sits on top of a computer monitor (connected to the computer by a cable) or that’s built into a laptop computer and is usually used to transfer live video.
The broadcast of audio or video content over the Internet. Unlike a podcast, a webcast is not updated automatically.
A location on the web.

A hacker who breaks into systems just for the challenge of it (and who doesn’t wish to steal or wreak havoc on the systems). Such hackers tout themselves as experts who are performing a needed service for society by helping companies realize the vulnerabilities that exist in their systems.
A surge protector that’s installed on (or near) the breaker panel of a home and that protects all electronic devices in the home from power surges.
A type of website that allows anyone visiting the site to change its content by adding, removing, or editing the content.
An operating system by Microsoft that incorporates a user-friendly, graphical interface.
Newest release of Microsoft’s operating system that provides, a new interface optimized for touch-screen devices.
Applications specifically designed to run in the Windows 8 interface; these apps are displayed full screen, without borders or controls.
New interface designed for Windows 8; features large type with clean, readable block images inspired by metropolitan service signs such as those found on bus stations and subways.
The main tool for finding, viewing, and managing the contents of your computer by showing the location and contents of every drive, folder, and file; called File Explorer in Windows 8.
A tool for allowing multiple people to share a Windows 8 computer while maintaining individual settings and preferences.
The 802.11 standard for wireless data transmissions established by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).
An ISP that provides service to wireless devices such as smartphones.
A device that amplifies your wireless signal to get it out to parts of your home that are experiencing poor connectivity.
A step-by-step guide that walks a user through the necessary steps to complete a complicated task.
Programs used to create and edit written documents such as papers, letters, and résumés.

definition.word: World Wide Web (WWW or the web)

glossary.definition: The part of the Internet used the most. What distinguishes the web from the rest of the Internet are (1) its use of common communication protocols (such as Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol, or TCP/IP) and special languages (such as the HyperText Markup Language, or HTML) that enable different computers to talk to each other and display information in compatible formats and (2) its use of special links (called hyperlinks) that enable users to jump from one place to another in the web.
A program that attempts to travel between systems through network connections to spread infections. Worms can run independently of host file execution and are active in spreading themselves.
A computer that’s controlled by a hacker who uses it to launch attacks on other computer systems.
Co-founder of Apple Computers.
Co-founder of Apple Computers.
Early computer language featuring word commands that was designed to make programming approachable for non-computer scientists.
Co-founder of Microsoft.
Co-founder of Microsoft.
Computer software and hardware corporation best known for its development of operating systems, such as Windows and DOS and the Office Suite of productivity apps.
Acronym for a group of early operating systems for IBM PCs and clones in the early 1980s.
Early operating system for microcomputers designed by Gary Kildall of Digital Research, Inc.
Microsoft’s DOS variant developed for IBM.
First spreadsheet program developed for PCs.
Early market-leading spreadsheet program developed for PCs.
Spreadsheet program that eventually supplanted Lotus 1-2-3 as the market leader.
Dominant word processing software in the early 1980s for microcomputers and PCs.
Microsoft’s first word processing software, eventually morphed into Word for Windows.
Dominant word processing software for PCs in the late 1980s.
Office machinery company best known for bringing photocopies to the masses.
Microsoft’s Internet browser software.
Web browser that helped make the World Wide Web accessible to the masses. First browser to display graphic inline with text instead of using a separate window.
Early, stable version of the Windows operating system introduced in 1995.
Netscape Navigator was the dominant web browser in the 1990s.
Mechanical calculator invented by Blaise Pascal in 1642.
French mathematician and inventor who invented the mechanical calculator in 1642.
French weaver and merchant who invented a programmable loom.
A programmable loom invented by Joseph Jacquard. Punch cards used for data entry in early computers were based on cards used by this loom.
An English mathematician and inventor who invented the first mechanical computer. Later designs for many types of computing machines were based on Babbage’s machines and theories.
A computer design by Charles Babbage that was unfinished at his death. Would have been the first computer that used punched cards for programming.
A mechanical calculator designed by Charles Babbage. Its purpose was to tabulate polynomial functions.
American inventor & statistician who developed a tabulating device that used punched cards to quickly compile data. His inventions provided the basis for the development of the first true computers.
An electromechanical machine designed by Herman Hollerith. It used punched cards to summarize information and was developed primarily to process data for the 1890 U.S. Census.
German inventor and computer pioneer.

Developed by Konrad Zuse in 1938, the Z1 was a floating point binary mechanical calculator featuring limited programmability. Its design helped pave the way for Zuse’s later developments in computing.
An early electronic digital computing device. Although not programmable, it was one of the first devices to use binary arithmetic.
Physicist who designed IBM’s Harvard Mark I computer.
Naval officer and computer scientist who developed the first compiler for a computer programming language. She was also one of the first programmers to work on the Harvard Mark I.
A program that understands both the syntax of the programming language and the exact structure of the central processing unit and its machine language.
First computing machine to automatically execute long calculations.

Widely acknowledged as the “father” of computer science and artificial intelligence, Turning was a mathematician and cryptanalyst. Developed the “Turning Machine” which used the ideas of an algorithm and computation to provide the basic design for a computer.
A hypothetical (not physical) device that automatically manipulates symbols according to a table of rules. This concept can be used to emulate the logic of any computer algorithm.
First electronic computer that could be reprogrammed and therefore solve a wide range of complex problems.
Co-designer of the ENIAC computer.
Co-designer of the ENIAC computer.
A line of computers developed and sold commercially by Mauchly and Eckert after their development of the ENIAC and their subsequent departure from the University of Pennsylvania.
Computers deployed from 1940 to 1956 that used vacuum tubes for circuitry, magnetic drums for memory, and punched cards for input.

Devices made from semiconductors that can both switch and amplify electronic signals. The transistor allows for the precise control of current moving through a circuit board and generates much less heat than vacuum tubes.

Computers deployed from 1956 to 1963 that used transistors instead of vacuum tubes, stored instructions in memory and used assembly languages. Still used punched cards for input and printers for output.
Electrical engineer who helped develop the first integrated circuit. Also invented the handheld calculator and the thermal printer.
A set of electronic circuits on a single chip of semiconductor material. Modern integrated circuits can have billions of transistors.
Computers deployed from 1964 to 1971 that used integrated circuits, input using keyboards, and output using monitors.

A chip that uses binary numbers and incorporates all the basic functions of a computer’s CPU on a single (or very few) integrated circuit. Microprocessors are programmable devices that accept input, process data and provide output.
Computers deployed from 1971 to the present that use microprocessors.
Networks that contain both servers (powerful computers that store programs and information) and clients (less powerful computers used for viewing and accessing data contained on servers).
Original term for a diary type website, now known as a blog.
Protocols that use encryption to protect data sent over the Internet.
The main protocol used by the World Wide Web. It facilitates communication between web browsers and web servers.
A computer running a specialized operating system that enables it to host web pages (and other information) and to provide requested web pages to clients.
attaching keyword descriptions to entries or images on a blog or social bookmarking site to facilitate organizing information into categories.
Social bookmarking sites allow users to organize bookmarks by assigning tags and sharing them with others.
A website on which users regularly post information or opinions on a regular basis.
The main high-speed data pathways on the Internet that facilitate moving vast quantities of information around the globe.
Establish a direct communication pathway between the brain and external devices allowing thought to director or control the device.
Techniques that involve the transplantation of devices that transmit electrical impulses to the brain for treating movement disorders such as Parkinson’s disease as well as chronic pain.
Self-renewing cells that generate the main characteristics of the central nervous system.
Devices inside the computer that are flipped between the two states of 1 and 0, signifying “on” and “off”.
Used as switches in the earliest generation of electronic computers; they allow or block the flow of electrical current.
Electric switches built out of layers of a semiconductor such as silicon. . Much smaller than and efficient than vacuum tubes, but were soon replaced by microprocessors.
Tiny regions of semiconductor material that support a huge number of transistors.
Chips that contain a central processing unit (CPU) of a computer system.
An organized plan for representing a number.
the number system used to represent values using the digits 0 – 9.
Numbering system that uses two digitals to represent all the values of a base-10 number system by describing a number as the sum of powers of 2.
Also known as binary number system, describes numbers in powers of 2, using just the digits of 1 and 0.

definition.word: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange)

glossary.definition: A consistent meanans of representing letters and characters in binary format. Represents each letter or character as an 8-bit (or 1-byte) bnary code.
A new encoding scheme that uses 16 bits instead of 8 bits used in ASCII.
whole numbers greater or less than zero.
a portion of 100, expressed by figures placed to the right of a decimal point.,
Alphabetic characters, and special graphical notations.
The first step in the machine cycle when the binary code is moved from Ram to the CPU.
The second step in the machine cycle when binary code is broken into commands the CPU understands.
The third step in the machine cycle when the CPU performs the work described in the commands, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division and other mathematical and logical operations.
The fourth and last step in the machine cycle when the result of the execution is placed in one of the registers of the CPU.
Special memory storage areas built into the CPU.

Part of the central processing unit (CPU) that manages the switches inside the CPU and that remembers the sequence of processing stages for the CPU, and how each switch in the CPU should be set (i.e. on or off).
A special crystal built into the motherboard that acts like a metronome to keep a steady beat and control when the CPU moves to the next stage of processing.
The steady beats or “ticks” of the system clock.
Block of memory built onto the CPU chip to store data or commands that have just been used.
A block of memory that is either located on the CPU chip (but slightly farther away than the Level 1 cache) or is located on a separate chip next to the CPU.
An additional third level of cache memory storage, to which the CPU looks for instructions and data after first checking Level 1 and Level 2 cache, but before accessing RAM.
Collection of commands a specific CPU can execute.
Long strings of binary code used by the control unit to set up the hardware in the CPU for the rest of the operations the CPU needs to perform.
The number of bits a computer can work with at a time.
A technique that allows the CPU to work on more than one instruction (or stage of processing) at the same time.
When individual computers in a large network of computers work on a portion of the same problem simultaneously.
A device that reads information from a magnetic strip on the back of a credit card–like access card.
A method to control which computer is allowed to use transmission media at a certain time.
In a network, a type of topology where the nodes participate in moving data through the network.
A server that acts as a repository for application software.
A server that keeps track of who’s logging on to the network and which services on the network are available to each user.
A heavily secured server located on a special perimeter network between the company’s secure internal network and its firewall.
A device that uses some unique characteristic of human biology to identify authorized users.
A device that’s used to send data between different collision domains in a network, depending on where the recipient device is located.
An attempt to access an account by repeatedly trying different passwords.
A system of networking connections in which all devices are connected in sequence on a single cable.
A characteristic of client/server networks where the server, not the individual user, coordinates data security.
A type of network that uses servers to deliver services to computers that are requesting them (clients).
A server that is maintained by a hosting company and that is connected to networks via the Internet.
A server that handles all communications between the network and other networks, including managing Internet connectivity.

The method used on Ethernet networks to avoid data collisions; short for carrier sense multiple access with collision detection. A node connected to the network uses carrier sense to verify that no other nodes are currently transmitting data signals.
When two computers send data at the same time and the sets of data collide somewhere in the connection media.
A server that provides client computers with access to information stored in databases.
A characteristic of peer-to-peer networks where the individual user coordinates data security.
A server used to fulfill one specific function, such as handling e-mail.
The exchange of large amounts of data in a standardized electronic format.
A server whose sole function is to process and deliver incoming and outgoing e-mail.
An area of an intranet that only certain corporations or individuals can access; the owner of the extranet decides who will be permitted to access it.
A server that stores and manages files for network users or that acts as a storehouse for files that users can download.
Groups of data packets that are sent together in a package.
A computer system that’s set up to attract unauthorized users by appearing to be a key part of a network or a system that contains something of great value.
Combining multiple topologies into one network.
Ensuring that information systems contain accurate information and are adequately secured against tampering.
A private network set up by a business or an organization that’s used exclusively by a select group of employees, customers, suppliers, volunteers, or supporters.
A special signal sent to network nodes alerting them that a data collision has occurred.
The physical address, similar to a serial number, of each network adapter.

Involves tasks such as (1) installing new computers and devices, (2) monitoring the network to ensure it’s performing efficiently, (3) updating and installing new software on the network, and (4) configuring, or setting up, proper security for a network.
The physical or logical arrangement of computers, transmission media (cable), and other network components.
A networking protocol established by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) that provides guidelines for modern networks.
Having an external screening router examine incoming data packets to ensure they originated from or are authorized by valid users on the internal network.
In a network, a type of topology where the nodes do nothing to move data along the network.
Any object that users carry to identify themselves and that grants them access to a computer system or facility.
A software holding area for print jobs. Also called a print spooler.
A server that manages all client-requested printing jobs for all printers on a network.
A set of rules for exchanging communications.
A server that acts as a go-between, connecting computers on the internal network with those on the external network (the Internet).
A type of network topology where computers and peripherals are laid out in a configuration resembling a circle.
A characteristic of client/server networks where more users can be easily added without affecting the performance of other network nodes.
Twisted-pair cable that contains a layer of foil shielded to reduce interference.
The most widely deployed client/server network topology, where the nodes connect to a central communications device called a switch in a pattern resembling a star.
A device that absorbs a signal so that it’s not reflected back onto parts of the network that have already received it.
A special data packet used to pass data in a ring topology network.
The access method used by ring networks to avoid data collisions.
The main technology for achieving a virtual private network; the placement of data packets inside other data packets
A network that uses the public Internet communications infrastructure to build a secure, private network among various locations.
Using specialized software to make individual physical servers behave as though they are more than one physical device.
A network made up of local area networks (LANs) connected over long distances.
Gives wireless devices a sending and receiving connection point to the network.
A special network adapter card that allows a computing device to connect to a network using wireless access.
A small application located on a server; when requested, the applet is downloaded to the client.
A list of rules that defines in one single location how to display HTML elements.
On a web server, a directory created by the network administrator who configures the web server.
A CGI program file.
Where a dedicated connection is formed between two points (such as two people on telephones) and the connection remains active for the duration of the transmission.
An Internet addressing scheme that allows a single Internet protocol (IP) address to represent several unique IP addresses by adding a network prefix
A model of network communications where a client device such as a computer, tablet, or smartphone uses browsers to request services from networks that make up the Internet.
A program that runs on the client computer and that requires no interaction with a web server.
Computers that host software that enables users to buy goods and services over the web.
A method of designing programs that provides a methodology by which a browser can request a program file be executed instead of just being delivered to the browser.
A set of rules for exchanging electronic information.
A protocol that a host computer can use to send data over the network without establishing a direct connection with any specific recipient computer.

A protocol for exchanging information that requires two computers to exchange control packets, thereby setting up the parameters of the data-exchange session, before sending packets that contain data.
Used by JavaScript to organize objects and page elements.
A server that maintains a database of domain names and converts domain names to Internet protocol addresses.
The form of an Internet protocol address, where sets of numerals are separated by decimals, i.e., 197.169.73.63.
A way of assigning Internet protocol addresses where a computer is assigned a temporary address from an available pool of addresses.
A protocol for assigning dynamic internet protocol addresses.
A combination of technologies—HTML, cascading style sheets, and JavaScript—used to create lively and interactive websites.
In HTML, a pair of tags and the text between them.
The process of coding e-mail so that only the person with the key to the code (the intended recipient) can decode the message.

A markup language that enables designers to define their own data-based tags, making it much easier for a website to transfer the key information on its page to another site; it defines what data is being described rather than how it’s to be displayed.
In a connection-oriented protocol, the process of exchanging control packets before exchanging data packets.
A digit with 16 possible values: 0–9 and A–F.
A programming language that tucks programming code directly within the HTML of a web page; the most popular example is JavaScript.
Tags that surround and define HTML content (such as <b> and </b>, which indicate bolding).
The Internet protocol that ensures data is sent securely over the web.
A section of the hard drive that stores information that may be needed again, such as Internet protocol addresses and frequently accessed web pages.

definition.word: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN)

glossary.definition: The organization that registers Internet protocol addresses to ensure they’re unique and haven’t been assigned to other users.
A way of connecting Internet service providers (ISPs) that’s made up of one or more network switches to which the ISPs connect.
The original Internet protocol addressing scheme, created in 1981.
An Internet protocol (IP) addressing scheme that makes IP addresses longer, thereby providing more available addresses.
The means by which all computers connected to the Internet identify each other. It consists of a unique set of four numbers separated by dots, such as 123.45.178.91.
A scripting language that’s often used to add interactivity to web pages; often used for creating Dynamic HTML effects.
The two keys used in public-key encryption.
Specification for sending files as attachments to e-mail.
In data exchange, the communication sent from one computer or system to another stating that it did not receive a data packet in readable form.
The slash and number added to the end of an internet protocol (IP) address that allows a single IP address to represent several unique IP addresses in classless interdomain routing.
A reference to each of the four numbers in a dotted decimal number internet protocol address, so called because each number would have eight numerals in binary form.
A system having the characteristic of being public for access by any interested party; as opposed to a proprietary system.
In data exchange, the confirmation sent from one computer or system to another saying that the computer has received a data packet that it can read.
A public-key package for encryption available for download on the Internet.
The key for decoding retained as private in public-key encryption.
A type of encryption where only the two parties involved in sending the message have the code.
