A system having the characteristic of being closed to public access (private), as opposed to an open system.
The key for coding distributed to the public in public-key encryption.

A type of encryption where two keys, known as a key pair, are created. One key is used for coding and the other for decoding. The key for coding is distributed as a public key, while the private key is retained for decoding.
A domain name system (DNS) server that contains the master listings for an entire top-level domain.
A domain that’s directly below a top-level domain.
A network security protocol that provides for the encryption of data transmitted using the Internet. The current versions of all major web browsers support SSL.
A type of program that runs on a web server rather than on a computer.
The protocol responsible for sending e-mail along the Internet to its destination; part of the Internet Protocol suite.
A way of assigning internet protocol addresses where the address for a computer never changes and is most likely assigned manually by a network administrator or an Internet service provider.
A communications line that carries digital data over twisted-pair wires.
The main suite of protocols used for transmitting data over the Internet. Named after Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and the Internet Protocol (IP).

In Transmission Control Protocol, the process used to establish a connection between two computers before exchanging data. The steps in a three-way handshake are as follows: One computer establishes a connection to the Internet service provider (ISP) and announces it has e-mail to send, the ISP server responds that it’s ready to receive, and the computer acknowledges the ready state of the server and begins to transmit the e-mail.
One of the original two protocols developed for the Internet.
An updated extension of Secure Sockets Layer
An Internet Protocol that creates data packets across the Internet.
One of the original two protocols developed for the Internet.
A high-speed fiber-optic line.
A communications methodology that makes computer communication efficient; in packet switching, data is broken into smaller chunks called packets.
A bank of modems, servers, routers, and switches through which Internet users connect to an Internet service provider.
In a database, confirms that only textual characters are entered in a field.
The branch of computer science that deals with the attempt to create computers that think like humans.
The accumulation of transaction data until a certain point is reached, at which time several transactions are processed at once.
See unstructured data.
Systems used to analyze and interpret data in order to enable managers to make informed decisions about how best to run a business.
Software used on company websites to capture information about each click that users make as they navigate through the site.
In a database, ensures that all required fields have been completed.
In a database, compares the values of data in two or more fields to see if those values are reasonable.
A digital collection of related data that can be stored, sorted, organized, and queried.
An information technology professional responsible for designing, constructing, and maintaining databases.
A specially designed application software used to create and mage databases.
When data is maintained in only one file.
A map of a database that defines the features of the fields in the database.
Data for a record being different in two different lists.
When the data in a database is accurate and reliable.
Small slices of a data warehouse grouped together and separated from the main body of data in the data warehouse so that related sets of data can be analyzed.
Duplicated data in a list.
The act of formatting data from source databases before fitting it into a data warehouse; it consists of three steps: extraction, transformation, and storage.

(1) Describes the kind of data being stored at the memory location; each programming language has its own data types (although there is some degree of overlap). (2) In a database, indicates what type of data can be stored in a field and prevents the wrong type of data from being entered into the field.
A large-scale collection of data that contains and organizes in one place all the data from an organization’s multiple databases.
A type of business intelligence system designed to help managers develop solutions for specific problems.
The value a database automatically uses for a field unless the user enters another value.
A report generated by a management information system that provides a list of the transactions that occurred during a certain time period.
A business intelligence system that accumulates in a central location all information relevant to running a business and makes it readily available to whoever needs it to make decisions.
A report generated by a management information system that shows conditions that are unusual or that need attention by system users.
A system that tries to replicate the decision-making processes of human experts in order to solve specific problems.
The component of a database in which the database stores each category of information.
A property that must be satisfied for an entry to be accepted into the field.
In an Access database table, the field name, data type, and other data elements.
Defines the maximum number of characters that a field can hold in a database.
In a database, temporarily displays records that match certain criteria.
In a relational database, the common field between tables that’s not the primary key.
Enables the interjection of experiential learning into knowledge-based systems by allowing the consideration of probabilities.
A system that includes data, people, procedures, hardware, and software that help in planning and decision making; a software-based solution used to gather and analyze information.
A beginning point.
A query used to extract data that’s in two or more tables in a database.
A business intelligence system that provides intelligence that supplements the user’s own intellect and makes the decision support system more effective.
A type of business intelligence system that provides timely and accurate information that enables managers to make critical business decisions.
In a relational database, records in one table are related to multiple records in a second table, and vice versa.
Data that describes other data.

Software that assists in building management models in decision support systems; an analysis tool that, through the use of internal and external data, provides a view of a particular business situation for the purposes of decision-making.
A database that stores data from different perspectives, called dimensions, and organizes data in cube format.
A knowledge-based business intelligence system that enables users to communicate with computer systems using a natural spoken or written language instead of a computer programming language.
process to ensure data is organized most efficiently in a database.
In a database, confirms that only numbers are entered in a field.
A type of analysis in which programmers first identify all the categories of inputs that are part of the problem the program is meant to solve.
A query language used by many object-oriented databases.
A system designed to improve communications and assist employees in accomplishing their daily tasks.
In a relational database, a record appears only once in one table while having the capability of appearing many times in a related table.
In a relational database, for each record in a table there’s only one corresponding record in a related table.
Software that provides standardized tools for viewing and manipulating data in a data warehouse.
The real-time processing of database transactions online.
In a database, a field that has a value unique to a record.
In a database, a way of retrieving information that defines a particular subset of data; can be used to extract data from one or more tables.
A specially designed computer language used to manipulate data in or extract data from a database.
Ensures that the data entered into the field of a database falls within a certain range of values.
The processing of database transactions in which the database is updated while the transaction is taking place.
A group of related fields in a database.
In a relational database, a condition where, for each value in the foreign key table, there’s a corresponding value in the primary key table.
The use of English-like expressions that have variables and operations, much like algebraic equations, to extract data from databases using Structured Query Language.
A database type that organizes data into related tables based on logical groupings.
In a relational database, a link between tables that defines how the data is related.
In Structured Query Language, displays a subset of data from a table (or tables) based on the criteria specified.
Data such as “Bill” or “345,” as opposed to unstructured data.
A database programming language used to construct queries to extract data from relational databases; one example of a fourth-generation language.
A report generated by a management information system that provides a consolidated picture of detailed data; these reports usually include some calculation or visual displays of information.
A group of related records in a database.
Data that doesn’t pertain to one period in time.
A type of business intelligence system for keeping track of everyday business activities.
Audio clips, video clips, pictures, and extremely large documents. Also called binary large object (BLOB).
The process of ensuring that data entered into a field of a database meets specified guidelines.
In a database, generally defined as part of the data dictionary and specified in the field properties for each field; violations result in an error message and a suggested action.
The programming language used by Adobe Flash; similar to JavaScript.
Programming language used to build websites with interactive capabilities; adapts an HTML page to the user’s selections.
A software product for developing web-based multimedia.
A collection of technologies that allow the creation of web applications that can update information on a page without requiring the user to refresh or leave the page.
A set of specific, sequential steps that describe exactly what the computer program must do to complete the required work.
A feature of Java whereby code needs to be compiled only once, after which the code can be run on many different CPUs.
In object-oriented analysis, the original class.
A type of decision point in an algorithm that can be answered in one of only two ways: yes (true) or no (false).
A programming language originally developed for system programmers.
A programming language; takes C to an object-oriented level.
A Microsoft programming language developed to compete with Java.
A category of input identified in object-oriented analysis; classes are defined by information and actions.
The step of programming in which a programmer types the code to be executed.
Translating an algorithm into a programming language.

A note left by a programmer in the program code to explain the purpose of a section of code, to indicate the date the program was written, or to include other important information about the code so that other programmers can more easily understand and update it.
The process by which code is converted into machine language—the language the central processing unit can understand.
General term used for a keyword in a programming language that allows the programmer to direct the flow of the program based on a decision.
Diagrams that trace all data in an information system from the point at which data enters the system to its final resting place (storage or output).
A tool in an integrated development environment that helps programmers analyze a program as it runs.
The process of running a program over and over to find and repair errors and to make sure the program behaves in the way it should.
A place where a program must choose from a list of actions based on the value of a certain input.
In object-oriented analysis, the modified class.

Description of the technical details of the software, how the code works, and how the user interacts with the program; in addition, all the necessary user documentation that will be distributed to the program’s users.
The ability of a web page to decide how to display itself based on the choices the reader makes.
A special tool in an integrated development environment (IDE) that helps programmers as they enter code.
The part of a problem statement where programmers describe what the program should do if the input data is invalid or just gibberish.
The binary sequence that instructs the central processing unit to run the programmer’s code.

A computer language in which a problem is presented as a series of facts or constraints instead of as a specific algorithm; the system of facts can then be queried; considered the most “natural” of languages.
The machine language of a central processing unit (CPU); the sequence of bits that the CPU understands.
Visual diagram of a process, including the decisions that need to be made along the way.

In Visual Basic, programmers use the keyword For to implement a loop; after the keyword For, an input or output item is given a starting value, and then the statements in the body of the loop are executed.
A computer language type that includes database query languages and report generators.
The point in the release cycle, where, after release to manufacturers, software is available for purchase by the public.
series of tags that define how elements on a website should be displayed in a browser.

In C++, a binary decision in the code where the program can follow one of two paths: If the decision is made one way, the program follows one path; if made the other way (else), the program follows another path.
In object-oriented analysis, the ability of a new class to automatically pick up all the data and methods of an existing class and then extend and customize those to fit its specific needs.
A beginning point.
A developmental tool that helps programmers write and test their programs; one IDE can be configured to support many different languages.
For a programming language, translates the source code into an intermediate form, line by line; each line is then executed as it’s translated.
An object-oriented programming language that has a large set of existing classes.
A small Java-based program.
Programming language used to build websites with interactive capabilities; adapts the HTML page to the user’s selections.
An error in a program that produces unintended or undesired output, where the syntax is correct but some other human error has occurred.

A type of decision point in an algorithm. In a loop, a question is asked, and if the answer is yes, a set of actions is performed. Once the set of actions has finished, the question is asked again, creating a loop. If the answer to the question is no, the algorithm breaks free of the loop and moves on to the first step that follows the loop.
The process of how a program converts inputs into the correct outputs.

In Visual Basic, programmers use the keyword Next to implement a loop; when the Next command is run, the program returns to the For statement and increments the value of the input or output item by 1 and then runs a test cycle.
An example of a class in object-oriented analysis.
The programming language most often used to program applications to run under OS X.
A database that stores data in objects rather than in tables.
A coding symbol that represents a fundamental action of the programming language.
A programming language; the only modern language that was specifically designed as a teaching language.
Programming language used to build websites with interactive capabilities; adapts the HTML page to the user’s selections.
The capability to move a completed solution easily from one type of computer to another.
The starting point of programming work; a clear description of what tasks the computer program must accomplish and how the program will execute those tasks and respond to unusual situations.
The process of performing a programming project, which consists of five stages: describing the problem, making a plan, coding, debugging, and testing and documentation.
A clear statement of the goals and objectives of the project.
The process of translating a task into a series of commands a computer will use to perform that task.
A kind of “code” for the set of instructions the central processing unit knows how to perform.
A small model of a program built at the beginning of a large project.
A text-based approach to documenting an algorithm.

An alternative program-development method; instead of developing detailed system documents before they produce the system, developers first create a prototype, then generate system documents as they use and remodel the product.
The point in the release cycle, where, after beta testing, a manufacturer makes changes to the software and releases it to other manufacturers, for installation on new machines, for example.
In object-oriented analysis, the ability to reuse existing classes from one project for another project.
An error in a program that occurs when a programmer accidentally writes code that divides by zero, a mathematical error.
An ever-changing set of requests from clients for additional features as they wait longer and longer to see a working prototype.
A simple programming language that’s limited to performing a set of specialized tasks.

A computer language that allows programmers to write programs using a set of short, English-like commands that speak directly to the central processing unit and that give the programmer direct control of hardware resources; also called assembly language.
A software update.
The instructions programmers write in a higher-level language.
A sentence in a code.
A database programming language used to construct queries to extract data from relational databases; one example of a fourth-generation language.
An agreed-on set of rules defining how a language must be structured.
A violation of the strict set of rules that define the programming language.

A process used to develop information systems; it consists of the following six steps: problem and opportunity identification, analysis, design, development, testing and installation, and maintenance and evaluation.
A check to see whether the loop in an algorithm is completed.

The part of the problem statement that lists specific input numbers the programmers would typically expect the user to enter; the plan then lists the precise output values that a perfect program would return for those input values.

A computer language that uses symbols and commands to help programmers tell the computer what to do, making 3GL languages easier for humans to read and remember; examples of 3GL languages include BASIC, FORTRAN, COBOL, C/C++, and JAVA.
A systematic approach in which a problem is broken into a series of high-level tasks.
Each input and output item the program manipulates.
Tells the operating system that the program needs to allocate storage space in RAM.
A subset of Visual Basic, used to introduce dynamic decision making into web pages.
A programming language used to build a wide range of Windows applications.

In programming languages that support Windows programming, programmers can use the mouse to lay out on the screen where the scroll bars and buttons will be in the application; the code needed to explain this to the computer is then written automatically.
Part of the Microsoft .NET Framework, programs that a website uses to make information available to other websites.
An information technology professional responsible for designing, constructing, and maintaining databases.
Employees with skill sets beyond the IT realm that are critical to getting projects accomplished (such as project managers).
People who create images for visual communication of ideas.

Responsible for ensuring the smooth functioning of computer networks including selection and installation of equipment, development and implementation of back-up and disaster recovery strategies, and diagnosing problems.
Encompasses all jobs integral to the creation and deployment of computer systems.
Any job that involves creating content for or programming a website.
People who create a series of images, either by hand or with a computer, to illustrate concepts and ideas usually with motion.
Any job that involves direct communication with a company's customers or supporting systems that customers utilize.
Facilitate communication with customers providing all levels of customer service.
Diagnose problems and repair computer equipment and software at an employee's or customer's location.
Designers and creators of databases.
Jobs that involve installing or supporting IT hardware infrastructure such as servers, network components and information storage systems.
Responsible for answering employee or customer questions regarding the function of IT systems, software or hardware.
Create schemes such as visual interfaces or menus that enable human beings to communicate with machines and software.
Outsourcing jobs to utilizing employees or firms located in other countries.
Responsible for coordinating and managing all personel on a systems development team to ensure the project is completed on budget and in a timely manner.
Generate the software code that enables computers perform tasks.
Responsible for developing and coordinating a company's strategy on all social media outlets on which the company has a presence.
Document systems (either manual or computer) and propose solutions to problems by designing computerized solutions.
Generate computer systems documentation for end users and programmers
Plan, install equipment and diagnose problems for a company's communications system.
People who generate video media.
People who generate the words and images that appear on websites.
Design and generate the software code that makes websites function.
Responsible for the setup, configuration and smooth operation of servers that host websites.
An automated attack that’s launched from more than one zombie computer at the same time.
Part of the CPU, responsible for performing all the arithmetic calculations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division). It also makes logic and comparison decisions.
see binary digit
see base-10 number system.
A base-16 number system that uses 16 digits (0-9, A-F) to represent numbers instead of the 10 digits used in base 10 or the 2 digits used in base 2.
Any material that can be controlled either to conduct electricity or to act as an insulator (to prohibit electricity from passing through).
An operating system that enables more than one user to access the computer system at one time by efficiently juggling all the requests from multiple users.

A personal computer designed by Xerox that included a word processor, file management system with directories and folders. It also included a mouse and could connect to a network. The Alto was not popular because of its very high cost.
The first personal computer built by Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs in Wozniak’s garage.
The first successful personal computer brought to market by Apple in 1983. Lisa incorporated many of the same features of the Alto.
Introduced a year after the Lisa, included the features of the Lisa, as well as a 3.5 floppy disk with a hard cover that replaced the larger 5.25-inch floppy.
The first portable computer made by the Osborne Company in 1981. The computer weighed 24.5 pounds and cost $1,795.
A keyword or term that Internet users assign to a web resource such as a web page, digital image, or video.
a type of non-volatile storage system (data is maintained when the power is turned off). Usually meant to imply a mechanical drive, using motors to rotate discs to read and write data.
anyone who works on the creation of a video game such as programmers
contracting an external party to perform an internal service for a business (such as hiring a company to clean your offices).
a person responsible for maintaining an entire (or any portion of) website.
microcomputer introduced in 1975 as a do-it-yourself kit (assembly required). Sparked the microcomputer revolution.
early computer language designed to use English words instead of complex code to make computer programming accessible to the masses.
used in firewalls, the process of examining packets to ensure they are from legitimate sources or belong to a particular (legitimate) stream of data.
extends SMS to include photos, video and audio as well as text.
IT professional who creates computer code for video games.
The process of allowing people to try out a prototype of a game in order to assess the playability and functionality of the game
